title: 111_s3810
content: The Act titled "Gulf Security and Iran Sanctions Enforcement Act" restricts participation in offshore oil and gas leasing. The Secretary of the Interior must include a certification requirement in each lease issued for drilling on the Outer Continental Shelf, ensuring that the lessee annually certifies they do not engage in activities subject to sanctions under the Iran Sanctions Act of 1996. Failure to make this certification may result in lease cancellation. The Secretary of the Interior must include a certification requirement in each lease for drilling on the Outer Continental Shelf, with the authority to cancel the lease if the lessee fails to certify compliance with sanctions under the Iran Sanctions Act of 1996. The Secretary, in consultation with other relevant departments, will cancel the lease if false certification is made. Additionally, the Secretary of the Interior is responsible for ensuring disclosure requirements are met. The Secretary of the Interior will cancel a lease if the lessee fails to make a required certification or provides false information. The Secretary must also include a disclosure requirement for energy-related activities outside Iran in leases issued for drilling on the Outer Continental Shelf. The Secretary of the Interior will cancel a lease if the lessee fails to disclose any participation in energy-related activities outside Iran involving blocked persons under Executive Order 13224. The curr_chunk discusses blocking property and prohibiting transactions with persons involved in terrorism, weapons of mass destruction proliferators, and entities listed on appendix A to part 560 of title 31, Code of Federal Regulations. The curr_chunk authorizes the Secretary to cancel a lease if a person fails to disclose involvement with terrorism, weapons of mass destruction proliferators, or entities listed on appendix A to part 560 of title 31, Code of Federal Regulations. The Secretary can cancel a lease if a person fails to disclose involvement with terrorism, weapons of mass destruction proliferators, or entities listed on appendix A to part 560 of title 31, Code of Federal Regulations. The Secretary may waive this requirement on a case-by-case basis with written certification to congressional committees. The Secretary of the Interior has the authority to waive the disclosure requirement for leases if it is in the national interest, with reporting requirements for waivers granted. The Secretary of the Interior must report to congressional committees on waivers granted and lease cancellations, with specific committees identified. In this section, "appropriate congressional committees" refer to specific committees in the House of Representatives and Senate. The term "person" is defined as per the Iran Sanctions Act of 1996. SEC. 3. SUNSET. The Act will end 30 days after the President certifies to Congress that Iran has permanently stopped supporting terrorism and pursuing weapons development. The Act of 1979 prohibits the pursuit, acquisition, and development of nuclear, biological, and chemical weapons and missiles, as well as any other provision of law, as long as it poses no significant threat to United States national security, interests, or allies.
